pages.text: The names given to actions by the ancients were certainly peculiar, but I think there's a certain kind of logic to them.$(br2)There seem to be certain groups of actions with common names, named for the number of iotas they remove from and add to the stack.

$(li)A $(thing)Reflection/$ pops nothing and pushes some number.$(li)A $(thing)Purification/$ pops one and pushes one.$(li)A $(thing)Distillation/$ pops two and pushes one.$(li)An $(thing)Exaltation/$ pops three or more and pushes one.$(li)A $(thing)Decomposition/$ pops one argument and pushes two.$(li)A $(thing)Disintegration/$ pops one and pushes three or more.$(li)Finally, a $(thing)Gambit/$ pushes or pops some other number.
Spells seem to be exempt from this nomenclature and are more or less named after what they do-- after all, why call it a $(thing)Demoman's Gambit/$ when you could just say $(thing)Explosion/$?
